title: How can 'pissed off' Dallas Cowboys snap three-game losing streak? Here’s two answers
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Week 6 had some stunning results but none bigger than the Cowboys loss to the winless New York Jets. As Trysta Krick details, they do have one saving grace. USA TODAY

FRISCO, Texas — Dallas Cowboys safety Jeff Heath explained it plainly.

“Obviously,” Heath said, “Guys are pissed off.”

Cowboys players riding a three-game losing streak have more than one reason to be.

They’re angry, even as they remain outwardly measured, that they’ve started so slowly. In their last three games, the Cowboys have scored a combined nine points before the half while opponents have raced to 47.

“We can play as well as we want to in the second half,” Pro Bowl right guard Zack Martin said. “But if you’re down, it’s tough to come back. … We’re built to get out and get off to a fast start and hold that league.”

Cowboys players are angry — as they look to right their offense — that they’re struggling to capitalize on big plays. Against the Packers, three interceptions derailed a 563-yard day on offense. Against the Jets, a passing attack without two starting receivers and both starting tackles looked to the run game to threaten. Instead, Ezekiel Elliott never gained more than 13 yards on any of his 28 carries. He was kicking himself about a 12-yarder he knew had potential for more. Ten times he advanced one yard or fewer.

“In your mind you start thinking like, ‘OK, well, you got this guy, this guy out [so] tighten my game up that much more,’” Elliott said. “Because like that second run of mine, if I would have scored there, that’s a different game. So, I mean, you can’t press. You can’t go out there tense. You can’t go out there and force a big play.

“It comes down to just executing our plays and not shooting ourselves in the foot.”

Cowboys players are angry, too, about shooting themselves in the foot.

Whether it’s the offense failing to convert in the red zone or the defense miscommunicating gaps on big plays, the units have struggled to emerge from the hole they’ve dug in the three-game skid.

Against divisional rival Philadelphia on "Sunday Night Football" this week, the Cowboys will look to channel that energy productively.

“It’s not always bad to be pissed and slam the table,” said Heath, who doesn’t describe himself as mad now or someone who feeds off negative emotions. But the defensive captain understands that teammates can channel frustration productively, he says, “as long as you can do that and get back to just being normal.”

Being normal is how the Cowboys hope to reverse course.

Elliott wants to keep running normally, or soundly, against the Eagles’ No. 2-ranked run D that’s allowed just 73.2 rushing yards per game. Sure it’s tempting to chase an early touchdown when Elliott hasn’t scored any of his five touchdowns this season in either the first or second quarter. But “bad stuff happens,” Elliott said, “when you go out there and try to do too much.”

Cowboys RB Ezekiel Elliott today.



Getting ready to face Eagles, who bring league’s No. 2 run D (72.8 ypg) pic.twitter.com/hY2c7kI5yh — Jori Epstein (@JoriEpstein) October 16, 2019

The Cowboys defense also wants to hone in on that normality, or consistency, against Carson Wentz and Co. as they maintain a stinginess on third downs (25.35 percent conversion allowed) that ranks second only to the New England Patriots. The unit is irked by its infrequent takeaways, averaging less than one per contest. Their two interceptions in six games, like their 0.8 takeaway rate, rank among the worst five in the league.

But Heath says that urge to “do something special” or make a big play to turn around a deficit is “the exact opposite” of what his unit should do. He points to cornerback Jourdan Lewis’ third-quarter interception of Sam Darnold as an example of Lewis simply doing his job well, following his instincts.

“When you’re down a couple scores and everything’s going wrong, it’s human nature to be like, ‘All right, what can I do to change this game?’” Heath said. “Just do your job and the ball hits you in the head.”

So the Cowboys won’t enter desperation mode as they fight the Eagles to claim first place atop the NFC East. Instead, the run game and secondary will seek consistency alone and leave any Hail Mary thoughts to the league’s third-best passing attack.

“Last year, we were 3-5 before we really got stuff going,” cornerback Chidobe Awuzie told USA TODAY Sports. “I feel like that kind of defined us as a team. Maybe somewhere along the way we kind of got comfortable or something. But I think it’s always backs against the wall.

“Now, more than ever, it’s that.”

description: Against the NFC East rival Philadelphia Eagles on "Sunday Night Football," the Dallas Cowboys will look to channel their anger productively.
